sections.title: Humble beginnings
sections.content:
My first encounter with software development was at 13 years old.

In 2016, I signed up for an annual youth robotics tournament organized by SPARK, in which my team and I won first place (3 years in a row!).

After my success, I acquired an interest in programming. I enrolled in a prestigious coding academy soon after, which I successfully graduated although I was by far the youngest person to ever attend that course. I learned what programming is, and how to make my first website. It was the starting point of my career.

sections.title: Hard work pays off
sections.content:
Spending a few years learning is nothing to ignore, and as I found out, practicing programming at home in your free time really pays off. During this time, I had to decide which area to specialize in: frontend, backend, mobile... It was hard to decide, so I naturally tried everything.

Nowadays I consider myself a full stack developer, capable of making web, desktop, and mobile applications, as well as backend servers, CLI tools, and games in multiple languages. It wasn't easy however - I was going to high school at the same time and I was also competing in multiple tournaments organized by my school.

(...in which my team, of course, won multiple times in a row again).

sections.title: The snowball effect
sections.content:
In 2022, high school was ending, which meant I really had to get serious about my future. I was still very cautious when looking for jobs or education opportunities, because I was unsure what I was getting myself into.

Thankfully, I didn't have to worry too much, because I got offered a summer internship! This was a great opportunity for me, and I learned a lot. In fact, I even got a job offer at the same company, which was quite a new experience to me.

I was a freshman in university at this point, so unfortunately I had to decline the job offer in favor of focusing on my studies.

Today, having experience behind my back, I'm looking for new opportunities to grow and learn.

techStack.name: Web
techStack.description: Stuff I use to make websites.

items.name: Frontend
items.description: Clientside UI-building tools that I used, currently use, or otherwise enjoy.

items.name: Javascript
items.description: What I started with, and what I still use and love.

items.name: Typescript
items.description: This is the flavor of JS I use most of the time.

items.name: React
items.description: My go-to library for building websites.

items.name: Svelte
items.description: Great for effective solutions and working fast.

items.name: Angular
items.description: A unique approach to building websites. I like it, but I don't use it often.

items.name: CSS
items.description: Having battled with CSS for years, I've found a few tools that I always keep under my belt.

items.name: Tailwind
items.description: A library of utility-classes to use instead of writing your own. This is my favorite way to write CSS.

items.name: shadcn/ui
items.description: The best React component library I've ever used. It has become a standard part of my frontend stack.

items.name: Material Design
items.description: This technically has nothing to do with CSS, but it's my favorite design spec.

items.name: Backend
items.description: Programming languages, frameworks, and services I use to develop APIs.

items.name: Java
items.description: A robust language with a lot of features. I use it for most backend projects I make nowadays.

items.name: Spring Boot
items.description: Having used it extensively in an internship, I like the way it handles backends. Makes complex projects easy.

items.name: NodeJS
items.description: Though there are better alternatives, NodeJS was was my first exposure to backend and it still holds up.

items.name: NestJS
items.description: My favorite way to write modular backends in NodeJS.

items.name: KoaJS
items.description: Quite a bit better than ExpressJS. Very enjoyable and easy to use.

items.name: Bun
items.description: A bit weird to label this as 'a subset of NodeJS', but Bun provides -a lot- OOTB, including a fast npm alternative.

items.name: SQL
items.description: Good ol' SQL.

items.name: MariaDB
items.description: My default database of choice.

items.name: Postgres
items.description: Like MySQL but with extra features that make sense to implement.

items.name: MongoDB
items.description: JSON is pretty nice. Having said that, I'd still rather use an RDBMS.

techStack.name: Mobile
techStack.description: What I use to make mobile applications (most of the time).

items.name: React Native
items.description: I love React and the ecosystem around it. Combined with Expo, it is very powerful and productive environment.

items.name: Flutter
items.description: I really like making desktop and mobile apps with it, but sometimes it feels a bit too verbose. Still one of my favorites for its performance and DX.

items.name: Firebase
items.description: My favorite BaaS. Comes in handy when I need a backend for my app, or an identity provider for my own custom backend.

techStack.name: Game Development
techStack.description: Mostly for fun, although it would be cool to make a full game someday...

items.name: Godot
items.description: The most fun I've had developing software in ages. It's very easy to use and it's one of my favorite tools.

items.name: Unity
items.description: My introduction to gamedev. It's actually pretty fun, but the age shows at times.

techStack.name: Miscellaneous
techStack.description: Random languages or tools I occasionally use.

items.name: Rust
items.description: I really like Rust, but I don't think I'm anyhwere near capable of using it.

items.name: Python
items.description: I use it for CLI tools, services, automation, and web scraping. Pretty handy.

items.name: Java
items.description: I use it to make Minecraft addons and mods, backends, or CLI tools and web scrapers.

items.name: C#
items.description: I had a light exposure to C# and I could imagine myself working with it in the future.

items.name: Pocketbase
items.description: A lightweight Firebase alternative which (IMO) has a better API, and uses SQL instead of NoSQL. Sounds too good to be true.
